awd_titl_txt: Aspects of Quantum Computational Universality in the Measurement-Based Models
awd_abstract_narration:
There are several approaches for building quantum computers that will potentially solve problems faster than today's classical computers.   One approach, called measurement-based quantum computation, requires "resource states" in order to work.  Resource states can be made with quantum mechanical systems such as ions, atoms, molecules, superconducting circuits, or elementary quantum states of light called photons. Yet there are still several open questions about how to characterize resource states.  This project will explore how different types of resource states are more or less resilient in the presence of noise. The project will also study how newly discovered phases in solids can be used as a resource states. The outcomes of this research project will promote progress by developing methods to characterize resources for quantum computation, and establishing intellectual connections between materials science and quantum information science. This project will also train students to develop new resources and designs for quantum computers. 

Quantum computers boast exponential speedup for certain tasks compared to classical computers. To realize this, designs studied here such as measurement-based models of quantum computation use local measurements on highly entangled states. Entanglement is thus a resource.  However there are still several fundamental questions about this type of resource.  For example, in addition to the cluster state and its generalization, it is not known what other states or other types of entanglement can support universal quantum computation.  It is also important to quantify the extent to which some resource states provide more resistance to noise than others.   This project will address those questions.  It will also investigate if resource states can emerge from certain phases of matter.  For example some states of matter recently found in condensed-matter physics possess topological order, either intrinsic or that protected by symmetry, that may serve as a resource for quantum computing.  More specifically, various symmetry-protected topologically ordered states in one, two, and three spatial dimensions (and intrinsic topological order states in two dimensions) will be studied to see whether they enable quantum computation via construction of new quantum gates, or reduction by local measurement to known types of resource states. Physical properties that enable computation using these states will be characterized. Furthermore, the question of whether these resource states with certain topological properties can lead to new fault-tolerant schemes will be investigated. The outcomes of the project will establish further connections between ideas in quantum information science and condensed-matter physics, and will contribute to the challenge of completely characterizing universal resources for quantum computations. This will contribute to progress designing quantum information processing systems that can be reliably experimental realized.

por.por_cntn:
Measurement-based quantum computation (MBQC) is a quantum computing approach that is known to achieve equivalent efficacy as other approaches, such as the standard circuit model. The way it executes computation is by measuring local quantum bits, initially in a certain highly entangled state. As measurement is being carried out, the entanglement is being consumed. Thus, entanglement is a resource for MBQC, and those states are called resource states. This project aims to broaden the scope of MBQC and has investigated the resource states from topological phases of matter, which consists of two kinds: (1) one that requires symmetry for their existence to be stable, called the symmetry protected topological (SPT) phase and (2) one that does not require symmetry at all, called the intrinsic topological phase.

The project outcomes and findings address a few intellectual merits and generate broader impacts on both the scientific aspects and quantum workforce training and development.

The PI and collaborators have strengthened the notion of quantum computational phases by establishing strong connection of SPT order to MBQC in one spatial dimension.  They showed that, for a wide range of SPT phases, the computational power is uniform throughout each phase, determined by the same algebraic information labeling the phase. This result has already impacted the later study of two-dimensional SPT phases for MBQC and was used to show the entire 2D cluster phase for quantum computation.

The PI and his former postdoc Dr. Ching-Yu Huang have worked on characterizing 2D SPT order and showed that there is an extended region in a 2D SPT phase diagram where the ground states are useful for universal MBQC. Furthermore, he and his students (Yanzhu Chen and Abhishodh Prakash) worked on qudit SPT states using the so-called decorated domain-wall construction. They uncovered and generalized 2D qudit graph-like states for universal MBQC and used that result to prove the qudit "hyper-graph" states on the triangular lattice (SPT phase with Zd x Zd x Zd symmetry) are also universal for odd prime d.

Spin models invented by Affleck, Kennedy, Lieb and Tasaki (AKLT) are paradigmatic examples of SPT phases. The PI and collaborators previously showed that ground states of many 2D AKLT models were universal resource for MBQC. Moreover, deformation of the system slightly away from the AKLT point can still retain the computational power. PI, his student Nicholas Pomata, and Dr. Huang studied a deformed spin-2 AKLT model on the square lattice using tensor-network methods and found that the phase diagram contains three different phases: antiferromagnetic, AKLT (very likely gapped) and XY phases. Whether these systems possess an energy gap above the lowest-energy state was an open question. Recently, the PI and Mr. Pomata demonstrated that 2D AKLT models on decorated square lattices were gapped. This result suggests that the universal AKLT states may be created by cooling down the system to very low temperature.

The PI and his students also studied intrinsic topological ordered states from the perspective of quantum computation. Using certain tensor-network representations, the toric code and the double-semion models can be used for MBQC, provided additional prior entangling operations can be made. In order to achieve universal quantum computation by only local measurements, three-dimensional quantum states may need to be used. Generalization of surface codes to certain 3D structures and to qudits does indeed allow universal MBQC.

This project has supported three PhD students at various stages and the PI worked closely with them in training their research and presentation skills. The PI also mentored several Master students. The PI also led a discussion group for undergraduate students in reading literature of quantum computation. A few of them have been continuing to do research projects with the PI. The PI also served as a research mentor in a summer research program for high-school students. In particular, he worked with one and taught him basics of quantum computing and how to use IBM's cloud quantum computers. The mentoring the PI provided to students at various stages of their career did impact on the workforce training and development for STEM and quantum research.

The PI co-organized a tensor-network workshop at Simons Center for Geometry and Physics in December 2017. It was interdisciplinary and there were a group of excellent speakers covering various topics. The tutorial sessions provided students and participants with useful hands-on experience. The talks were recorded and archived, and they could potentially reach audience broader than the workshop participants. The PI also co-organized the "Quantum Immersion Workshop" held on Stony Brook University campus in February 2019 and gave an introductory talk on "Quantum Algorithms and Programming Environments". All oral presentations were recorded and posted to YouTube, and the impact they will have can also be broader than expected.
